message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Modal Dependence Logic
Paper Abstract: We introduce a modal language which involves the concept of dependence. We give two game-theoretic definitions for the semantics of the language, and one inductive, and prove the equivalence of all three.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about Dependence Logic:

## Overview

Dependence logic is a logical formalism, created by Jouko Väänänen, which adds dependence atoms to the language of first-order logic.

## Key Characteristics

Dependence logic is a logic of imperfect information, like branching quantifier logic or independence-friendly logic (IF logic): in other words, its game-theoretic semantics can be obtained from that of first-order logic by restricting the availability of information to the players, thus allowing for non-linearly ordered patterns of dependence and independence between variables.

A significant distinction is that dependence logic differs from these logics in that it separates the notions of dependence and independence from the notion of quantification.

## Expressiveness

Dependence logic is a conservative extension of first-order logic: in other words, for every first-order sentence according to the usual first-order semantics. However, dependence logic is strictly more expressive than first-order logic, and every dependence logic sentence is equivalent to some sentence in the existential fragment of second-order logic, conversely, every second-order sentence in the above form is equivalent to some dependence logic sentence.

## Semantics

The team semantics for dependence logic is a variant of Wilfrid Hodges' compositional semantics for IF logic.

Based on the search results, here's information about Dependence Logic:

## Overview

Dependence logic is a logical formalism, created by Jouko Väänänen, which adds dependence atoms to the language of first-order logic.

## Key Characteristics

Dependence logic is a logic of imperfect information, like branching quantifier logic or independence-friendly logic (IF logic): in other words, its game-theoretic semantics can be obtained from that of first-order logic by restricting the availability of information to the players, thus allowing for non-linearly ordered patterns of dependence and independence between variables.

A significant distinction is that dependence logic differs from these logics in that it separates the notions of dependence and independence from the notion of quantification.

## Expressiveness

Dependence logic is a conservative extension of first-order logic: in other words, for every first-order sentence according to the usual first-order semantics. However, dependence logic is strictly more expressive than first-order logic, and every dependence logic sentence is equivalent to some sentence in the existential fragment of second-order logic, conversely, every second-order sentence in the above form is equivalent to some dependence logic sentence.

## Semantics

The team semantics for dependence logic is a variant of Wilfrid Hodges' compositional semantics for IF logic.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of game theory:

## Definition and Overview

Game theory is the study of mathematical models of strategic interactions.(no content)It has applications in many fields of social science, and is used extensively in economics, logic, systems science and computer science.(no content)It is now an umbrella term for the science of rational decision making in humans, animals, and computers.

## Historical Development

Modern game theory began with the idea of mixed-strategy equilibria in two-person zero-sum games and its proof by John von Neumann.(no content)His paper was followed by Theory of Games and Economic Behavior (1944), co-written with Oskar Morgenstern, which considered cooperative games of several players.(no content)Initially, game theory addressed two-person zero-sum games, in which a participant's gains or losses are exactly balanced by the losses and gains of the other participant. In the 1950s, it was extended to the study of non zero-sum games, and was eventually applied to a wide range of behavioral relations.

## Key Concepts

Nash's most famous contribution to game theory is the concept of the Nash equilibrium, which is a solution concept for non-cooperative games, published in 1951. A Nash equilibrium is a set of strategies, one for each player, such that no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally changing their strategy.

## Major Applications

Fifteen game theorists have won the Nobel Prize in economics as of 2020, including most recently Paul Milgrom and Robert B. Wilson, highlighting the field's significance in economics and beyond.

Links: [{"title":"Syntax and semantics of logic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntax_and_semantics_of_logic_programming"},{"title":"Semantics (logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantics_(logic)"},{"title":"Semantics of logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantics_of_logic"},{"title":"Algebraic semantics (mathematical logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algebraic_semantics_(mathematical_logic)"},{"title":"Syntax (logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntax_(logic)"},{"title":"Semantics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantics"},{"title":"The Cartesian Semantics of the Port Royal Logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Cartesian_Semantics_of_the_Port_Royal_Logic"},{"title":"First-order logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First-order_logic"},{"title":"Formal semantics (natural language) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_semantics_(natural_language)"},{"title":"Categorical logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Categorical_logic"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of semantics in logic:

## Definition

In logic, the semantics or formal semantics is the study of the meaning and interpretation of formal languages, formal systems, and (idealizations of) natural languages.

## Key Approaches

The development of formal semantics has led to several influential approaches, including model-theoretic semantics (pioneered by Alfred Tarski), proof-theoretic semantics (associated with Gerhard Gentzen and Michael Dummett), possible worlds semantics (developed by Saul Kripke and others for modal logic and related systems), algebraic semantics (connecting logic to abstract algebra), and game semantics (interpreting logical validity through game-theoretic concepts).

## Model-Theoretic Semantics

The most widespread approach is based on the idea that the meaning of the various parts of the propositions are given by the possible ways we can give a recursively specified group of interpretation functions from them to some predefined mathematical domains: an interpretation of first-order predicate logic is given by a mapping from terms to a universe of individuals, and a mapping from propositions to the truth values "true" and "false".

## Proof-Theoretic Semantics

Proof-theoretic semantics associates the meaning of propositions with the roles that they can play in inferences.

## Role in Logic and Language

The study of interpretations is called formal semantics. This field is essential because the truth conditions of various sentences we may encounter in arguments will depend upon their meaning, and so logicians cannot completely avoid the need to provide some treatment of the meaning of these sentences.

Links: [{"title":"Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_logic"},{"title":"Normal modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_modal_logic"},{"title":"S5 (modal logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S5_(modal_logic)"},{"title":"Epistemic modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_modal_logic"},{"title":"Dynamic logic (modal logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_logic_(modal_logic)"},{"title":"Regular modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regular_modal_logic"},{"title":"Category:Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Modal_logic"},{"title":"Non-normal modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-normal_modal_logic"},{"title":"Modal operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_operator"},{"title":"Temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temporal_logic"}]

Here are the search results for Modal Logic:

## Overview

Modal logic is a kind of logic used to represent statements about necessity and possibility.(no content)In philosophy and related fields it is used as a tool for understanding concepts such as knowledge, obligation, and causation.

## Basic Components

Modern treatments of modal logic begin by augmenting the propositional calculus with two unary operations, one denoting "necessity" and the other "possibility".(no content)The notation denotes "necessarily p" by a prefixed "box" (□p) and a prefixed "diamond" (◇p) denotes "possibly p".

## Types of Modal Logic

There are several ways to interpret modal operators in modal logic, including at least: alethic, deontic, axiological, epistemic, and doxastic.(no content)The smallest logic satisfying certain conditions is called K. Most modal logics commonly used nowadays, such as C. I. Lewis's S4 and S5, are normal (and hence are extensions of K).

## Historical Development

C. I. Lewis created the first symbolic and systematic approach to modal logic in 1912.(no content)It continued to mature as a field, reaching its modern form in 1963 with the work of Saul Kripke.

## Applications

Dynamic logic is an extension of modal logic capable of encoding properties of computer programs.(no content)Temporal logic has found an important application in formal verification, where it is used to state requirements of hardware or software systems.

There are several ways to interpret modal operators in modal logic, including at least: alethic, deontic, axiological, epistemic, and doxastic.(no content)The smallest logic satisfying certain conditions is called K. Most modal logics commonly used nowadays, such as C. I. Lewis's S4 and S5, are normal (and hence are extensions of K).

## Historical Development

C. I. Lewis created the first symbolic and systematic approach to modal logic in 1912.(no content)It continued to mature as a field, reaching its modern form in 1963 with the work of Saul Kripke.

## Applications

Dynamic logic is an extension of modal logic capable of encoding properties of computer programs.(no content)Temporal logic has found an important application in formal verification, where it is used to state requirements of hardware or software systems.

todos.activeForm: Editing triples_output.json with all triple data

todos.content: Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
